titlegrp.title: GPS collars are more efficient when collecting high-frequency data

author.details: Australian Wildlife Conservancy, Mornington Wildlife Sanctuary, PMB 925, Derby, WA 6728, Australia.
Australian Wildlife Conservancy, Mornington Wildlife Sanctuary, PMB 925, Derby, WA 6728, Australia.
School of Zoology, University of Tasmania, Private Bag 55, Hobart, Tas. 7001, Australia.
School of Zoology, University of Tasmania, Private Bag 55, Hobart, Tas. 7001, Australia.

front.abstract: Selecting an appropriate fix schedule has a pivotal role when using GPS collars. On the basis of deployments of GPS collars on 35 cats, we report on an often overlooked consideration: that GPS units are more efficient collecting data at high frequencies (15min between fixes in this study) than low frequencies (>2h between fixes).
